bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, February 12, 1948

div1.p: Hench writes that he is looking forward to examining Agramonte's papers. Hench wants the original records in order to reveal the true story behind the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, February 12, 1948
div1.opener:
February 12, 1948
Senora Estella Agramonte de Rodriguez Leon
Calle K No. 254
Vedado, Havana
Cuba
My dear Senora:
div1.p:
At long last Mrs. Hench and I are returning to Cuba. We will be at
the Villa Atlantique, Palm Beach, Florida, from Friday, February 20, to Sunday,
February 29, and plan to come by boat, arriving at the Hotel Nacional, Monday
March 1, to stay for about a week. I have much to do and many people to see,
most important and most pleasant of all will be the opportunity to see you again.
I note from your Christmas letter how busy you are and I will try not to bother
you more than once. Perhaps we might have a little preliminary conversation at
your convenience and then if it would serve your convenience, I could hire a
stenographer. I could ask you certain questions and the stenographer could trans-
cribe our interview, allowing you to see the transcription and alter it later in
any way you saw fit. I am most anxious to learn something of the material that
you found in the old trunks. I am also anxious to know whether your mother's
diary may have helpful information in it. A long time ago, I believe we dis-
cussed the possibility that you might be able to find some extra reprints of
your father's, that I haven't been able to get. I am wondering if the correspon-
dence between your father and the editor of the Scientific Monthly might have
been preserved; this is in connection with the article which your father wrote
for the Scientific Monthly, December 1915.

A letter from your father to Mrs. Lazear, years ago, stated that your
father had given the address at the unveiling of Lazear's statue in the Finlay
Park, across from the main building of the Department of Sanitation (I think
that is the building). I have not been able to find your father's address.
Perhaps it was not published and the manuscript might be available somewhere.
After Reed read in English the paper of the Board at the Pan-American Congress
in Havana, February 1901, your father read a Spanish translation of the paper.
A copy would be of great interest.

Most important of all, would be the discovery of your father's records
of his experiments with mosquitoes, interspersed with notes by Reed, which
records of your father he mentioned in a letter to General Kean dated July 3,
1908.

I hate very much to bother you like this, however, there is no question
but that there are still certain people in the United States who are inclined to
discount, somewhat at least, your father's contribution. Certain articles, letters
and records available to this country have given them support for their attitude
and it is this attitude that I am so anxious to counteract. About the only way
I can do it effectively is to find the pertinent and concrete records of what
your father did from time to time. Unfortunately, your father did not escape

Senora Rodriguez Leon

what happened to every one connected with the affair (and to all of us for that
matter). As the years passed by and as he wrote or spoke from time to time of
the affairs of 1900, his memory evidently played tricks and he contradicted
himself here and there, sometimes rather importantly. This is quite under-
standable. Everyone else connected with the affair contradicted himself,
many remembered things that never happened, etc., and I have been able to
weave my way fairly successfully through the contradictions but it is important
for anyone who wishes to give the true story of your father's contribution
to get the support of further records if they might be available. You have
been such a wonderful help in the past I will try so hard not to impose upon
you unduly and I am sure you know of my great desire to present the story
truthfully with fairness to all concerned.

Should you wish to give me any instructions, I enclosed a stamped
envelope (I found the Cuban stamps left over from my 1941 trip).
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PAH:alc
